text:
Washington Square Park, the eastern side, seen from the S.E. corner,
with One Fifth Avenue in the background.
May 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square East - 5th Avenue
folder: Washington Square East & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

text:
Washington Square Park, eastern half, seen across the Square from
a building near the S.W. corner.
This view is almost straight east on Washington Square South (4th Street), showing the Judson Memorial Church (1892) and the clearing made about 1927 on the S.E. corner of Thompson
Street.
August 1, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, but a little further to the north, showing part of the new One Fifth Avenue apartment hotel (1926), and not
showing Washington Square South.
The apartment building on the N.E. corner of University and Waverly Places was erected in 1929. Compare both these views
with Ewing Galloway's picture taken about 1924.
August 1, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - 5th Avenue
folder: Washington Square South & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

text:
New York University, Washington Square East, from Washington to Waverly Places, showing 1-2 Washington Square North. This is the new building, erected about 1900 on the site of the old New York University building, and at first occupied by the
American Book Company.
July, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square East - Washington Place
folder: Washington Square East & Washington Place, Manhattan, NY

text:
(1)
78,80, and 81-4 Washington Square East, from West 4th Street to Washington Place. The building occupied by The Celluloid Company was erected around 1895 after demolition of the Asbury Methodist-Episcopal Church, which has stood on that corner. About the same time the Vischer building, shown on the N.E. corner of Wooster and 4th Streets, was erected. 80 Washington Place, in the middle of the block, is the old Benedick, an
apartment house.
September 8, 1905.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  N3eS W 5' 0
(2)
The same block, twenty-eight years later, seen from the middle of the Square. These buildings now belong to New York University; they were taken over not long after 1925.
February 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same block, seen from 71 Washington Square South.
July, 1935.
L. Sperr.
1  L.
L1

title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Place

text:
14-22 Washington Square North, looking west from Fifth Avenue.
These fine old residences antedate the Civil War.
In front of No. 15 is the spot where Sandy Hill Road, a part of
which has become Greenwich Avenue and another part of which has
become Astor Place, crossed the main branch of Minetta Creek in
the 18th Century. It is possible that this was the crossing at
which the old "Kissing Bridge" was located.
February 24,1922.
Gift of E.M. Jenks.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 5th Avenue
folder: Washington Square North & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

text:
Washington Square North, east from about 8 Washington Square. These old reSidences contrast with the receatly erectes 21-story apartment building on the N.E. corner of Waverly Place and University Place, built in 1929. In the right foregrouns is shown part of Washingtow Arch, giving a very good profile view
of Washington.
About 1931.
Ewing Galloway.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  Mle0 W 5 9
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 4th Street (West)
folder: Washington Square North & 4th Street (West), Manhattan, NY

text:
1-13 Washington Square North, (right to left) north side, from University Place to Fifth Avenue as seen from the roof of 71 Washington Square South, across the Park, with the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue in the foreground and the midtown skyscrapers in the background. The Empire State Building (1930) rises behind 55 Fifth Avenue, to the center of the picture. To the right of same appears the Metropolitan tower (1907) and the New York Life Bldg.(1926) and the Chrysler Bldg. (1930) at 42nd Street. Partially shown in a decapitated form in the foreground, is No. 1 Fifth Avenue, a modern Apartment house.
July 1935.
Views 1 and 2
P. L. Sperr.
No. 3.
An eastward view of the same row of buildings as photographed from Fifth Avenue. In the background,at the S.E. and N.E. corners respectively of Waverly Place,appears the law department of New York
University and a new Apartment house.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place
folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY

text:
1-13 Washington Square North, from University Place to Fifth Avenue, seen across the N.E. corner of the park. The view on University Place is north along the west side, up to Union Square. These old houses, except No. 3, the building with the fire escapes,
are old residences antedating the Civil War.
In the right background may be seen the Metropolitan Life Insurance
tower at Madison Avenue and 24th Street.
Around 1926.
Ewing Galloway.  Neg. # 582
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place
folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY

text:
(1)
3-13 Washington Square North, north side, from but not including University Place to but not including Fifth Ave., with the new No. One Fifth Ave. apartment hotel rising in the background. The view is across the Square from the S.E. corner.
December 28, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, showing more of the S.E. side of Washington Square Park.
February 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
Neg # 583
(3)
The same, two years later, as seen from the S.E. corner of Washington Square.
The Empire State Building, in the far background, has been erected
since the date of the previous view.
July. 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
